captions.text: I have a confession to make.
When I was invited [br]to come and speak here,
I felt honored, I felt joy
and the next day I felt bewilderment.
And the reason I felt [br]that bewilderment
was because when we agreed [br]on the title of the speech,
I said to myself, how is it possible for me to talk
about something so self-evident to me.
Usually the hardest things are [br]the self-evident ones, aren't they?
It's like someone told me, come and [br]talk about the importance of oxygen in life.
Come and talk about the value[br]of your mother's love for you.
Or freedom's. I considered it [br]very self-evident.
And if I had just myself across from me,
this one slide would be enough.
I would say that science is an inner need,
a panhuman trip we all want to make,
we all have a thirst [br]for knowledge anyway,
some more, some less, [br]but we all have it.
And usually we're just looking [br]for the right channel
and this event today is such a channel
and today's speakers are the guides.
So I would stop there, but [br]I don't want to stop here, obviously.
I want to talk about more practical results
that we'll have if we put [br]more science in our life.
And I have some points I want to elaborate on
and later I'll also talk about how I believe
the communication of science [br]should take place.
I'll start with this nice gentleman, [br]do you recognise him?
(Laughter)
He's the actor, I can't remember his name, [br]from the movie "My Big Fat Greek Wedding",
of the Greek-American Nia Vardalos
and the reason why I put him [br]on the first slide is that whenever I think
of science and how much it defines our life
- we live in a scientific world -
I remember that this gentleman had this thing.
He was the typical Greek [br]immigrant restaurant owner,
in ancient-Greek kitsch, he didn't want [br]his daughter to marry a foreigner,
and he liked to tell Americans,[br]"Give me a word"
«Give me a word, give me a word [br]and I will show you the root of this word is Greek».
Ok, I sound like Borat now.[br]You've heard him.
That's how I feel about science.
Show me an aspect of your life,[br]one of your activities,
a time of your day[br]that isn't flooded with science.
So since we live in a scientific world,
we have to make a lot of decisions together
about how, when, and for how long [br]will this tool called science be used.
I think it is inconceivable to talk about [br]nuclear energy, for example,
about a catastrophe that happened[br]in Fukushima two years ago,
and journalists running to get [br]a statement from Remos and Mazonakis.
We must all be informed [br]about what nuclear energy means
and the scientists out there must be
the first to talk about it.
And this is a good example,[br]nuclear energy.
Imagine if tomorrow or the next day we said
that for our energy needs we want [br]to build a nuclear plant.
And the Turks, for example, [br]have talked about it.
Our neighbours in Bulgaria [br]already have one.
Can you imagine what would happen?
Just for a landfill all hell broke loose.
Imagine that we said we are[br]beginning talks on nuclear energy.
Greenpeace, political parties, [br]local communities, business interests.
It would be a madhouse.
I don't think there would [br]even be a discussion.
So we he have to put more [br]science into our lives,
because we have [br]to be trained and to understand
that we can't base our decisions,
that we'll make tomorrow [br]or the next day about our energy,
our environment, our food,
on emotional reflexes
or misinformation by journalists
who, ok, can't know everything[br]to the maximum degree.
So more science to make [br]more dialogues when we have to.
In fact, the gentleman in the movie [br]believed that with glass cleaner
he could cure all skin conditions.
So that brings me to my second point.
To develop critical thought.
Kostas mentioned something [br]earlier about chemtrails.
I'm sure that if I ask each one of you,
anyone who wants to can come and[br]discuss with me during the break,
and I ask him "Are you a rational person?"
He will answer "Yes".
"Do you respect western science?"
He will answer "Yes".
"Do you respect the way western science [br]works, do you trust it completely?"
He will answer, [br]"Yes, of course. I'm a rationalist."
That's what everyone will tell me.
But if I make a list - ok, chemtrails [br]is a bit more extreme -
zodiac signs, let's see, [br]tarot cards, quantum-psycho...
We paste some scientific words[br]and supposedly give...
If I give you a list of 10 things that
western science does not accept, [br]considers arbitrary,
at least one - ok let's not hide -
you probably believe in [br]at least one of them, don't you?
Out of courtesy I have [br]to say that I do too.
(Laughter)
I'll give you a quiz.[br]What's this in the middle.
What am I trying to show with [br]the little glass in the middle.
Come during the break [br]and tell me if you found it.
So at school they taught us that [br]we had to develop critical thinking,
to doubt things,
and know how to tell apart[br]the arbitrary from the reasonable.
The pointless, from [br]what makes sense, right?
And that critical thinking, which[br]was never developed at school,
the truth is that they cultivated memorization,
will protect us from other things, as well.
It will protect us from populists,[br]from hypocrites.
And the reason we are all victims [br]in this country of hypocrites
is because we never developed[br]critical thinking in other things too.
So more communication of science,
more science in our lives.
Ok, it won't be a vaccine,
the results won't be visible the next day,
but it will be something [br]like a long term cure.
Technology doesn't sprout.[br]What do I mean by that.
The next time you have an ultrasound,
to see if your baby is alright in the womb,
that you put a pacemaker in your father,
that you have eye laser-surgery,[br]so you can see,
and say "How nice science is,[br]it gives quality of life,
it gives us so many things",
then ask yourselves what [br]can you do, so that we can continue
to have this production of technology.
The next time you're sorry[br]for young Greek scientists
leaving abroad, [br]again, ask yourselves,
"Ok, I'm sorry, but what can I do?"
The most important thing you can do [br]is to support politically.
Forget parties, forget ideas,[br]ideologies, signs,
forget all that and say,
which one of the politicians[br]will really talk about the protection
of researchers and scientists in this country.
Because we'll rely on them[br]if we want to talk about development.
We can't talk about fires[br]and ignore the firemen.
And no country ever advanced financially[br]without technological development.
(Applause)
But for all this to happen,[br]the new generation has to come as well.
In most scientific professions there is a [br]decline in the young people that follow them.
And for good reason.
Because the scientist stereotype[br]we have is the one you see.
Google the word "scientist".
You'll get a caricature.
You'll get that crazy 65-year old with fluffy hair
who has a glint in his eye[br]and wants to destroy the world.
Not all scientists are like that,[br]although I've met a few of them.
But they are also scientists, these girls.
And I'm not pointing at them [br]because they're women,
and because we consider[br]science to be dominated by men.
They are the winners [br]of the 2012 L'Oreal awards.
Meaning they are at the top [br]of their professions.
So let's also change the stereotypes.
And this brings me to the second part[br]of my presentation.
What I want to tell you is this.
80% of Europeans state that [br]they are interested in science.
That's what surveys say,[br]I've got a link up there that shows it.
While 65% are interested in sports.
So why[br]-and this is the large paradox-
so why since we all say "But yes, [br]obviously I'm interested in science".
But why do we run to stadiums,[br]theatres, movies, anywhere,
except science.
There is a large strugle to pull in people,[br]to make science popular.
This is the paradox.
And that's the mistake [br]that all educators make.
This is my message [br]to the communicators of science,
and to the teachers and educators[br]of universities and everywhere:
"Learn to tell apart the interesting [br]from the attractive."
For people to come close to science[br]they have to have a good time as well.
That's why they go elsewhere, [br]because they have a good time.
They say, "You're doing a fine job,[br]when you find the cure for cancer,
let us know. Until then [br]PAOK-Aris is playing."
(Laughter)
So the reason that science [br]isn't yet popular
is because that's where all of us,[br]who call ourselves educators, fail.
And communicators. [br]And we have to separate that.
We have to change our mentality
and with some of my own actions[br]I have discovered that in the recent years.
for example I did science theatre [br]with some of the young scientists here,
that I met through a contest.
And the response I had was amazing.
That was the first revelation for me.
I saw children of every class, [br]and it'a very difficult
to hold the interest of a class [br]of 100-200 people, children.
I saw adults, I saw families[br]go crazy with what we showed them.
Why? Because they had a very good time[br]and at the same time they learned.
Of course science must become open [br]and democratic and accessible,
but efforts are being made there.
Where there isn't much effort [br]being made yet is in this part.
To make science pleasant and fun.
There are a lot of ideas,[br]and science theatre is something
that I have worked on.
In England, pubs fill up[br]to hear maths.
Because people like Matt Parker[br]do stand-up comedy with maths.
People have a good time and learn.
Mark Lewley next door plays the guitar[br]and talks about string theory.
Let's learn to make it [br]fun and attractive.
The fact that something is interesting [br]and you have it in your mind as interesting
doesn't mean that everyone else[br]will run to listen to you.
These are some of the ideas [br]I show out there,
I do it more so that you get inspired.
Because I'm sure that you can[br]bring many of your own ideas.
Apostolos Doxiadis, who is a writer,
wrote best-seller mathematics books.
How did he do that? Because he put[br]in them elements from other things
which are fun, elements [br]which are in a classical novel.
Like with the "Sophie's world".
It made philosophy popular for the first time.
Because we put in there [br]heroes, mystery, humor.
So take something that's[br]already popular and that people like
and use it as your vessel [br]to communicate what you want.
Even the contest through which[br]I started το intensively occupy myself with,
that's why it succeeded.
Scientific contests are abundant.
Especially in America, every school[br]and university has its own contest.
But this one worked because[br]it took on the format of other contests,
the well known talent shows, [br]that focus on arts, artistic activities.
It took this format and miraculously,[br]millions of people
started watching Fame Lab.
So this is what I hope for.
I hope that we find inspiration, [br]that we find new motives,
that we find new reasons[br]for more science in our lives,
it will protect us from a lot of things,
and things we haven't thought of,[br]even political and social.
I hope for a time when Q is the[br]charming hero, the gadget-man.
With the purpose of making society,[br]our society but others too,
from a society of prejudice,[br]to a society of information.
>From a society of injustice [br]and foolishness
to a society of remarkable.
Thank you very much.
(Applause)

title: Η σημασία της επιστήμης στη ζωή μας και στη κοινωνία: Σπύρος Κιτσινέλης at TEDxAcademy
